definition:
The function [*hyperbolic sine integral*]{} (in Latin [*sinus
hyperbolicus integralis*]{}) from $\mathbb{R}$ to $\mathbb{R}$ is
defined as $$\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Shi}{x} \,:=\, \int_0^x\frac{\sinh t}{t}\,dt,\end{aligned}$$
or alternatively as
$$\operatorname{Shi}{x} \,:=\, \int_0^1\frac{\sinh{tx}}{t}\,dt.$$\
It isn’t an elementary function. The equation (1) implies the Taylor
series expansion
$$\operatorname{Shi}{z} = z\!+\!\frac{z^3}{3\!\cdot\!3!}\!+\!\frac{z^5}{5\!\cdot\!5!}
                \!+\!\frac{z^7}{7\!\cdot\!7!}\!+\cdots,$$ which
converges for all complex values $z$ and thus defines an entire
transcendental function. Using the Taylor expansions, it is easily seen
that $$\operatorname{Shi}x \;=\; i\,\operatorname{Si}{ix}$$ connects Shi
to the sine integral function.\
$\operatorname{Shi}{x}$ satisfies the linear third differential equation
$$xf'''(x)\!+\!2f''(x)\!-\!xf'(x) = 0.$$
